title: Creates new view on popup and overlay
UI does not show when focused within the editing window of a Google Doc
body: Unexpectedly, 1f92debb055b8fc567fb6d297292d78f786587ce fixed #2 along with #25. But for some reason, the UI (hold key indicator and tab search) does not show when you activate hold keys while focused within the editing window. As before, everything works normally if you click out of the editing window (e.g. top of the page). Needs investigation to figure out what's going on. I suspect it's more than just CSS because a quick glance at the console suggests that tab search is not being activated at all, not just being hidden under something.

title: Within iframes, content script should defer action to the top-level window
body:
A quick, manifest-only change enabled the content script to be injected into iframes, including dynamically generated ones (fixing #25). But it's not a complete solution, because now the UI runs within the iframe, which looks particularly weird with small windows like on hangouts.google.com. The only case where it's a more than cosmetic problem is tab search, where the results can be obscured within a small window. I think it's still rather an edge case, and the work-to-UX-gains ratio is high.

To fix it, we can follow an approach like in https://stackoverflow.com/a/12904047, which is where I started for the solution to #25.

title: Move CSS to a preprocessor like Sass or Less
body: We don't have a lot of CSS yet, but it's good to do anyway for tidiness. Maybe could even be part of a larger framework use that could eliminate the coupling between CSS and constant selector strings in the JS.

title: KeepTabs settings should not sync across browsers/devices
body:
Since different browsers means different computers, it's quite likely the user doesn't want their hotkeys to sync across browsers (e.g. wants different hotkeys for work and home computers). It's particularly important for if the user is running on different OSes -- then we have to make sure the hold key setting isn't syncing.

Maybe the best solution would be to have an option for whether to sync across browsers, with default to no.

This should be pretty simple to do; it's just a matter of using local storage instead of chrome.sync. Might be a bit tricky with the option to do either.

title: Left/right nav hotkeys (with alt) are blocked by window snapping shortcuts on ChromeOS
body: Alt+left/right snap the current window to the left or right half of the screen on ChromeOS, making alt a not so good default hold key for ChromeOS. The only other choice would be Meta (Search key), though I don't know if that would even work since the OS search shortcut would probably override KT I imagine. Ideally this should be fixed by allowing customization of the built-in hotkeys as suggested in  #33.

title: Ensure that new user installation runs smoothly

milestone.title: v1.0.0 Release Ready
milestone.description: The issues that must get closed before release!

body:
1. We should probably have an [onInstalled](https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/runtime#event-onInstalled) page pop up like some extensions, with some README-like information on how to use the extension and maybe direct the user to options (KeepTabs doesn't do that much until you've added some hotkeys).
2. We also need to consider how to make the extension work a) immediately upon install and b) after an update. I think the way b) works is the browser auto-updates when the extension isn't running; i.e. in our case when the browser is fully closed. That's okay-ish, although many users probably never fully close Chrome and might instead try manually updating/reloading -- which would break KT functionality until they reload their tabs, as we've always dealt with in development. a) also needs thought, because tabs currently open when the user installs KT will not have the content script, and so won't have KT active on them. I think there's a way to inject the content script into those pages for a seamless experience. Both these items can be explained away in the onInstalled page, but of course it's better to have it be automatic and seamless for the user.

title: Improve UI of over-screen tab search
body:
I wrote 004ff6ce0eb62d86f85159d1f4b36f191bda2530 pretty fast to get #27 done so Roger could work on some stuff without worrying about our background and content script diverging a lot and having a messy merge. But there are some UI improvements that I didn't have time to figure out, mostly related to weird stuff happening with the tab search filtering (maybe related to fuse):

1. Even though I call `populate()` when opening the tab search, no results show until the user inputs something; this differs from the original popup tab search behavior and isn't horrible, but it would be better if it just showed all the tabs at the start.
2. The fuse fuzzy search seems to be keeping some state and "remembering" the previous search, as even after backspacing and deleting all the characters, the results are different (related to previously typed characters) than a plain list of all the tabs.

title: Use the current tab from the stack instead of chrome.tabs.query
body: When we need to get the currently active tab, we previously had to use `chrome.tabs.query({[CURRENT_WINDOW]: true, [ACTIVE]: true})`, as the Chrome API recommends for getting the current active tab. But because we keep track of all tab changes for our tab history stack, we can instead just get the id of the current tab from the top of the stack instead of incurring the overhead of an extra API call. We should look through the code and switch over any leftover query calls.

title: Restructure code to use ES6 modules
Add a "mouse mode" enabling hold key + scroll wheel to do left-right nav (experimental)
body: A rather obscure tab navigation feature on Chrome is the ability to use the scroll wheel on the tab bar to do left-right (no wraparound) tab navigation. It's actually pretty nice, but having to be on the tab bar is a little weird. It would be cool to try having this feature enabled by holding the hold key instead of having the cursor on the tab bar. In particular, this gives the user a way to switch tabs with only one hand on the keyboard (the current left-right nav requires two; #33 also addresses this), particularly when they're already using the mouse with the other hand. I find this is a pretty common use case for myself, and it results in me still sometimes clicking to switch tabs (gasp). Definitely more of an experimental (#49) feature though.

title: Create a list of regression tests to manually run before pushing code
body: This would serve as a checklist of functionality to manually test before pushing any code, to ensure that nothing was broken by the commit. Maybe make it in the Wiki section.

title: Set a tab to have a hotkey that you set
body: On any given tab (whether it has a hotkey or not), you should be able to set a new hotkey to it. Once that tab is closed, even if you open another tab to the same link, the hotkey you set will no longer be in effect.

title: Implement more levels of logging and reconsider levels of existing log messages
body: The existing Info, Warning, Error levels are good, because we can set the logging level to Error when we publish to the Chrome web store (and maybe you only want Warning sometimes when debugging?). But the (background script in particular) console log is starting to get a little cluttered as the extension does more and more, and there are definitely distinct levels of log messages that are all using LOG_INFO right now (e.g. major user-level actions like "Navigate to previous tab" and fine implementation details (good for debugging) like when the `last_window_id` or `last_tab_id` are updated). Maybe even just one more level for the finer details, LOG_DEBUG or something, would be enough. Google's [glog](http://rpg.ifi.uzh.ch/docs/glog.html) even provides a integer argument-specified VLOG macro that allows you to specify an arbitrary integer logging level, but I think that's too far (as well as hard for multiple contributors to intuitively agree on in their usage, because what does logging level "4" mean?). @Sophtware, what do you think?

title: Implement one-hand versions for built-in hotkeys (left-right nav, etc.)
body: Even for the current default hold key (escape), all the built-in hotkeys are nice and intuitive, but they can't be performed with one hand (even given my caps lock mapped to escape). It would be nice to have a one-hand (particularly, left hand) version of them available for when you have one hand on the mouse, as you might for certain types of web browsing. You could even just use some of the alphabet keys on the extreme left, like q, w, a, z. In that case, we'd probably have to make them fully customizable (in case the user would rather pick other letters). The other question is whether they should exist in addition to or replacing the current defaults. The former seems kind of confusing, so I'm thinking the latter. This seems relatively simpler to implement too as the built-ins would basically become like normal customizable hotkeys (customizable on the options page) but with special preset functionality (and we'd also allow non-alphabet hotkeys for these). This should probably be implemented along with #1.

title: Add bookmarks as another category of tab search results
body: It should be visually separate, and definitely underneath/less prominent than the currently open tabs. But this would be pretty neat for opening up bookmarks (those that you need to preserve the link, but you don't go to it often enough to make a hotkey for it) quickly.

title: make saving hotkeys more user-friendly

milestone.title: v1.0.0 Release Ready
milestone.description: The issues that must get closed before release!

body: It's easy to make a new hotkey and then just close the window. We should have autosaving (or give the save button a better UI, maybe always keep it on the screen).

title: Overwrite the URL of the current tab when a hotkey is called from a "new tab"
Fix up the UI of the options page

milestone.title: v1.0.0 Release Ready
milestone.description: The issues that must get closed before release!

body: It was okay during the hackathon, but it's pretty ugly

title: Add ability to switch directly to any tab (even if it does not have a hotkey assigned to it)
body:
Do this by putting the hotkey that corresponds with the tab in its title like:
[f]Facebook
If the tab does not have a hotkey preset for it, generate a hotkey for that tab that fits its name and does not conflict with other hotkeys.

title: Write README

milestone.title: v1.0.0 Release Ready
milestone.description: The issues that must get closed before release!

body: Fill in the README.md explaining how to use KeepTabs. Write it in such a way that we can also use it for the description on the [Chrome web store](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/keeptabs/jlmlcpjfdggbankookliljdemjikjfog).
